Oh I didn't realize this would be too much trouble. I'm fine with leaving it the way it is. But just as future reference, the site also supports html tables, see an example:

* Code: #!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/annotate/80a94085e105eb4532a60ebede07752b5164c0e7/ros_urdf/tutorial.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#tutorial.md-155
* Rendered: http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=ros_urdf#HeaderofaURDFFile

content.raw: I think it's best to use `ignition::math` on the examples and call `.Ign()` to convert to `gazebo::math` as needed. Note that `gazebo::math` is fully deprecated on Gazebo 8.
content.html: I think it's best to use ignition::math on the examples and call .Ign() to convert to gazebo::math as needed. Note that gazebo::math is fully deprecated on Gazebo 8.

content.raw: Does Gazebo7 use ignition math? Should I split the tutorial for the two versions?
content.html: Does Gazebo7 use ignition math? Should I split the tutorial for the two versions?

content.raw:
Gazebo 7 accepts ignition-math 2, but it has many API calls, including some used here, which only accept gazebo math. While on Gazebo 8 these calls have been deprecated... 

The use of Gazebo math has been discouraged since we started supporting ignition, so I think we should only use it where strictly necessary, such as old API calls.

So I guess the only solution is to create two separate tutorials... How about starting with one just for Gazebo 7 and adding another for Gazebo 8 later?
content.html:
Gazebo 7 accepts ignition-math 2, but it has many API calls, including some used here, which only accept gazebo math. While on Gazebo 8 these calls have been deprecated...

The use of Gazebo math has been discouraged since we started supporting ignition, so I think we should only use it where strictly necessary, such as old API calls.

So I guess the only solution is to create two separate tutorials... How about starting with one just for Gazebo 7 and adding another for Gazebo 8 later?

content.raw: On Gazebo 8+, this accepts `ignition::math`
content.html: On Gazebo 8+, this accepts ignition::math

content.raw:
It would be interesting to provide an example which users can use straight away. This looks like it still requires the user to write some of their own code until they can use it right?

In fact, I think all the functions added here are super useful for a lot of people, and it might be worth it porting them to Gazebo eventually.
content.html:
It would be interesting to provide an example which users can use straight away. This looks like it still requires the user to write some of their own code until they can use it right?

In fact, I think all the functions added here are super useful for a lot of people, and it might be worth it porting them to Gazebo eventually.

content.raw:
Great work! It looks like you did some pretty exhaustive research!

The only thing I've noticed is that there is a lot of information and this might be overwhelming for users. There are hints here and there mentioning why one method would be preferred over another, but in general, someone looking at this for the first time might be confused as to what method they should choose, what are the pros and cons and so on. I do realize this is not easy to put together though.
content.html:

There are hints here and there mentioning why one method would be preferred over another, but in general, someone looking at this for the first time might be confused as to what method they should choose, what are the pros and cons and so on. I do realize this is not easy to put together though.
